text: most scones are served with Jam on the
side but these scones have the jam baked
right in this jam recipe is a little bit
different from others because I'm using
honey instead of sugar what's great
about the honey is that you can
caramelize it really easily and it just
adds an extra depth it goes really well
with plums so I'm going to pour the
honey in a pan and I'm just gonna let it
bubble for a few minutes until it starts
to deepen in color you want about a
medium brown don't want it to burn if it
does start to burn add a little bit of
water to the pan it'll cool it off it'll
stop the cooking so you can see as the
honey heats up it runs all over the pan
it gets nice and loose this is gonna
take about 2 or 3 minutes so if you
haven't cut up your plums all nice and
neat in a bowl like this you could be
doing it at the same time you see how
this honey is turning dark right now I'm
gonna add a fresh bay leaf and when we
have the plums to the pan it stops the
caramel from over browning because
they're so juicy the bay leaf is adding
a little bit of a spicy flavor to this
kind of a piney flavor but you can also
do rosemary instead or a cinnamon stick
would be nice you're looking for these
plums to get brown and tender but not
fall apart I mean these look ready to me
so it goes really quickly we just want
to put them in a bowl to let them cool
the juices are gonna thicken as this
cools and chills so you don't have to
worry about really thickening it up but
if your plums are super juicy and you
notice that there's a lot of liquid in
the pan what you could do is take your
slotted spoon remove the solids and then
just boil down the syrup for a minute or
two so I've got cornmeal in this bowl
and all-purpose flour some sugar baking
powder and salt
I just want to whisk it all together and
then I'm gonna add my butter you could
do this in a food processor if you'd
rather it goes really quickly so
basically what I'm doing right now is
I'm just pinching the butter into the
flour mixture the butter should be in
pea-sized pieces kind of like that I
know I'm gonna add cream and egg and
I've already mixed them together in a
measuring cup I'm looking for a soft
dough that just holds together and I
probably won't need all of this and then
whatever is left I'm gonna brush on the
top this is looking good you want to
walk the line here between handling this
as little as possible but getting it
well mixed when you squeeze it it should
stick to itself and kind of come
together as a nice
now you just cut it into wedges and then
just separate them so they get brown on
all sides here is a little tip if you
want them to be softer and less Brown
you keep them very close together if you
want them browner
and a little bit crunchy you separate
them and leave lots of space now to get
the jam inside the scones I'm just going
to use my thumb and press a divot deep
into each scone use your leftover cream
and egg mixture to brush on top of the
scones if you ended up using all of your
cream and egg mixture to get the scone
dough to be the right texture then just
use a little bit of cream just to brush
the tops spoon the jam right into these
divots looks very beautiful bake these
at 400 until golden brown even though
these scones come with their own Jam you
still should use lots of butter
